skill.name: nmap
skill.description: Professional network reconnaissance and port scanning using nmap. Supports various scan types (quick, full, UDP, stealth), service detection, vulnerability scanning, and NSE scripts. Use when you need to enumerate network services, detect versions, or perform network reconnaissance.
skill.summary: Professional network reconnaissance and port scanning using nmap. Supports various scan types (quick...
skill.author: BrownFineSecurity

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill providing nmap guidance. No executable code. Emphasizes authorization and ethical use. Legitimate security testing tool documentation.

content.user_title: Scan networks with nmap for reconnaissance
content.value_statement: Network reconnaissance is essential for security assessments and system audits. This skill provides step-by-step guidance for professional port scanning, service detection, and vulnerability identification using nmap.
actual_capabilities: Run comprehensive port scans using multiple scan types
Perform service version detection on discovered ports
Execute NSE scripts for vulnerability assessment
Parse and analyze nmap output for key findings
Apply appropriate timing templates for different scenarios
Scan network ranges, CIDR blocks, and multiple hosts
limitations: Requires nmap to be installed on the system
Some scan types require root or sudo privileges
Does not perform exploitation or credential testing
User must have authorization before scanning targets

use_cases.title: Network security assessments
use_cases.description: Perform authorized reconnaissance during penetration tests and security audits.

use_cases.title: Asset discovery and inventory
use_cases.description: Identify open ports and services across managed networks and systems.

use_cases.title: Service inventory verification
use_cases.description: Verify exposed services and ports on development and production environments.

prompt_templates.title: Basic port scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Scan host 192.168.1.100 using the default two-phase strategy. Save results to ./nmap-output/.

prompt_templates.title: Service enumeration
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform service detection on target 10.0.0.5. Run version detection and default NSE scripts.

prompt_templates.title: UDP assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: Run UDP scan on target 192.168.1.50 focusing on top 100 UDP ports.

prompt_templates.title: IoT device scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Scan IoT device at 192.168.1.200 using full port range. Check for RTSP, HTTP, and MQTT services.

best_practices: Always save scan output using -oA flag for multiple formats
Use two-phase strategy: port discovery first, then service detection
Verify authorization before scanning any target system
anti_patterns: Running scans without saving results to files
Skipping host discovery retry when host appears down

faq.question: Does this skill require nmap installation?
faq.answer: Yes. The system running the scans must have nmap installed. Install via package manager: apt-get install nmap or brew install nmap.

faq.question: What scan types require root privileges?
faq.answer: SYN stealth scan (-sS), UDP scan (-sU), OS detection (-O), and raw packet features require root or sudo access.

faq.question: Can this skill integrate with other tools?
faq.answer: Yes. Nmap output can be parsed and imported into other security tools, vulnerability scanners, and reporting systems.

faq.question: Is scan data stored or transmitted?
faq.answer: No. All scan results remain local on the system. This skill only provides guidance and does not transmit data externally.

faq.question: Why are my scans timing out?
faq.answer: Use -T4 for faster scanning, limit port range with -p, or use --top-ports to reduce scope. UDP scans are inherently slower.

faq.question: How does this compare to other scanning tools?
faq.answer: Nmap is the industry standard for network reconnaissance. It offers extensive scriptability via NSE and flexible output formats compared to alternatives.
